For the **Soul** (*hún*) has already melted into the spirit-*qi*, and the **Grain Spirit** (*gǔshén*) has merged with the revived primordial command to become the **initial foundation of the Yang Spirit** (*yángshén zhī chūjī*).
Though the Heavenly *qi* has already returned to the body, the Yang Spirit is just forming—
like the faintest glimmer of the **Toad’s light** after the Winter Solstice (*dōngzhì*), which still requires **warming and nourishment**.
The light has not yet fully emerged from the eaves, hence the saying: *“the Cold Toad emits radiance toward the Jade Eaves”* (*hán chán shè yù yán*).

The fool notes: **The Gold Elixir’s three hundred days of cultivation** (*jīndān sān bǎi rì gōngfū*)
commences at this stage, when **preheaven true *qi*** (*xiāntiān zhēnqì*) begins to condense into spirit, allowing one to advance the Dao/Way without obstruction.
Recently, other alchemical texts (*dānshū*) describe this stage and hastily write of the **Yang Spirit manifesting** (*yángshén xiànxíng*), yet this is still **spirit dispersing** (*shénchí*).
If they say it manifests within the body, it is still unsatisfactory.
As for the phrase *“manifesting form”* (*xiànxíng*), I do not know from where its phantom image arises.
The **Pure Yang Master’s** (*Chunyáng Zǐ*) *Qiaocao Song* [Divining-Stick Strike Song] states:
*“With three lead, one lead is obtained, yet the Golden Fruit and Immortal Herb have not yet manifested form.”*
This serves as proof!

○ **Chapter Fifty-Four**.」

「This follows upon the preceding chapter, elucidating the intent of **urgent rectification** (*zhènglìng*), which is the **Dao of division and gestation** (*fēntāi*). Indeed, its foundation has long been laid in the **hidden subtlety** (*yòumì*) of **preheaven true *qi*** (*xiāntiān zhēnqì*) through day and night! Thus, when **original essence and destiny** (*yuánmìng*) return to their source, this is the **success of the Valley Spirit** (*Gǔshén chénggōng*), the moment when one may **retain form and not die** (*liúxíng bùsǐ*)—the **initial formation of the Pure Yang Spirit** (*zhèngyángshén chūjié*).

The **nurturing and warming** (*wēnyǎng*) practices are detailed in **Chapter Sixty-Four** and beyond, while the following nine chapters expound upon the **essentials of returning the elixir** (*huándān*) and further reinforce the **exhortation to earnest practice** (*quànmiǎn zhī cí*).

---
**The Pearl within the Shell is easily split, the Hen’s Egg within the Nest is readily found.**
From **nothingness, somethingness arises** (*wúzhōng shēngyǒu*), as **spirit-*qi*** (*shénqì*) naturally interpenetrates.
It speaks of how even **subtle things** (*wéiwù*) know to **remain still and focused** (*jìngzhuān*) until **somethingness is achieved** (*yǒuchéng*).
Like the shell containing the pearl, like the hen brooding the egg—all belong to **somethingness arising from nothingness** (*wúzhōng néngshēng yǒuwù*).
Thus, one’s **elixir Dao** (*dān dào*) must be **steadfast and sincere** (*héngchéng*).
Only when **spirit-*qi* is steadfast and unshaken** (*shénzhù bùyí*), when **concentrated *qi* yields softness** (*zhuāngqì zhìróu*), and when **subtlety is sustained without interruption** (*mìmì miánmián*), will **spirit-*qi* naturally interpenetrate and coalesce**—this is all there is to it.
○ **Chapter Fifty-Five**.»
This uses **material analogies to illustrate human practice** (*wùyǐ pìrén*), and further implies the **Dao of natural nurturing and warming after division and gestation** (*fēntāi hòu zìrán wēnyǎng*). Can humans not surpass even these analogies?

---
**Spirit-*qi* is not parent-child, the body-mind is not husband-wife.**
But only when one **harmonizes with the celestial mechanism** (*hé tiānjī*), will anyone recognize the **place where the elixir is formed** (*jié dān chù*).
This is due to the **master-transmitted alchemical texts** (*shīchuán dānshū*) of former generations, which often use terms like **parent-child** (*zǐmǔ*) and **husband-wife** (*fūfù*), to metaphorically describe **spirit-*qi* and body-mind** (*shénqì shēnxīn*).
The **parent-child analogy** (*zǐmǔ zhī yù*) is still too disjointed, while the **husband-wife analogy** (*fūfù zhī yù*) falls into the error of **deliberate fabrication** (*wàngzuò*).
Thus, I particularly clarify that these are metaphors for **spirit-*qi* and body-mind** (*shénqì shēnxīn*), not actual **parent-child** (*zǐmǔ*) or **husband-wife** (*fūfù*).
I instruct students not to be **entangled in the literal wording** (*ní dānwén*), but only to comprehend the **timely celestial mechanism** (*shí míng hé tiān jī*), which begins with **action** (*yǒuwéi*) and ends with **non-action** (*wúwéi*).
**Refining yin essence** (*yīnjīng*) into **Pure Yang Spirit** (*yángshén*)—
when **spirit condenses and *qi* gathers** (*shénníng qìjù*), the elixir naturally forms.
If asked where the elixir is formed, it is only within **formlessness and profound seclusion** (*wúxiàng yōudú*), where **perfect substance arises from nothingness** (*wánzhì shēngxiàng*).
It is merely the **practice of nurturing *qi*** (*yǎngqì zhī shí*), where the **substantial essence of concentrated spirit** (*shénníng zhī shí*) is directed toward **stillness and emptiness** (*jìngxū*), and the **void of condensed spirit** (*shénníng zhī xū*) returns to **my steadfast substance** (*wú dūshí*).
With time, it becomes **strong and robust** (*gāngjiàn*), and thus **radiance emerges** (*suǐyǒu guānghuī*).
Therefore, the **Pure Yang Spirit manifests** (*yángshén xiànxíng*), and the **celestial *qi*** (*tiānqì*) returns—who can truly recognize this?

○ **Chapter Sixty-Nine.**
This is an exhortation to the multitude, declaring all may learn together.

A broken house is easily repaired,
a spent medicine is not hard to regrow.

then gold and treasure will accumulate like mountains.

Though the previous chapter declared all may cultivate,

Yet the **Supreme Authentic Alchemy** of the **Complete Reality** requires no aged materials—

knowing no division of youth or age.
A single moment of **spirit’s stillness** is a moment of **Grain Spirit** (*gǔshén*),
a single moment of **clear vital intent** is a moment of **Original Qi** (*yuánqì*).
If one steadfastly guards this moment’s **spirit**, one nourishes this moment’s **qi** in circulation.
Thus, through unbroken, enduring practice,
**qi nourishes spirit**, spirit condenses, and **essence spontaneously generates qi**.
As **essence daily thrives**, spirit grows vibrant—
**spirit-water** irrigates, the **Sea of Qi** fills,
and **yang-qi** naturally ascends, penetrating upward,
condensing **essence into spirit**.
When **spirit is complete** and **qi is full**,
one reverses aging, returning to infancy—
this is the **Law of Return**.
What difficulty is there in the **medicine**?
Thus I liken the body to a house:
if one but wills to repair it, it will soon mend.
The **medicine within** is not hard to regenerate—
only gather the mind, refine the heart, and conceal them in secrecy,
and **spirit will return**, **qi will restore itself**.
Day by day, month by month,
gold and treasure will pile like mountains within—
as **Zhūyáng Zhāngzǐ** said:

This continues from the previous chapter,

In sum, so long as breath remains, life and nature still belong to me.
When spirit stands firm and unyielding,
qi flows ceaseless and continuous—
this resolve must not falter in the least.

The following three chapters then expound the **Law of Return**.

The soul and vital essence form three natures,
spirit and qi gather the Five Phases.
Within them, four symbols divide,
concentrating to form the embryonic essence.

Human nature is fundamentally one,
bestowed by Heaven (as the field above, grass below) upon my heart,
while soul and vital essence reside in liver and lungs,
originally not permitted to stand alongside the heart.

The Master Qú remarked:
*“Before cultivation, the heart of right and wrong is indeed one’s innate nature.
Its branches and offshoots, its conflicting tendencies—
these are the work of the soul;
its partiality and stubbornness, its disregard for justice—
these are the work of the vital essence.”*

Li Shàn’s annotation in the *Wénxuǎn* states:
*“The soul is the essence of the body, the vital essence the resolve of nature;
both can divide the authority of true nature.”*
This principle is most clear.

Thus, when ordinary people encounter matters,
their first thought is pure and clear—
rooted in the heart, it is true intention;
but when a second thought arises,
it is the soul’s doing—
though doubt may linger, it is not yet wholly corrupt;
until the third thought decides,
it is the vital essence’s creation—
pure yin, entirely selfish.
Man has but one nature,
yet the heart, seduced by external things, cannot discern good from evil,
and thus allows soul, vital essence, and intention to rule together—
a state of three ministers in one kingdom.
Hence it is said: *“The soul and vital essence form three natures.”*

Yet the soul of the East Wood truly gives birth to the spirit of South Fire,
and the vital essence of West Metal truly generates the essence of North Water.
The Dao of the Elixir draws from spirit and qi,
which in turn depend on soul and vital essence for their origin—
thus soul and vital essence are the mother of spirit and qi,
and spirit and qi are the sign of life and nature.
Therefore, one must gather the Five Phases into one
to fully achieve the Dao of the Elixir.

The Classic says:
*“To sincerely intend, first perfect knowledge;
when knowledge is perfected, one exhausts principle and nature reveals itself.”*
Thus, those who cultivate must first exhaust principle and perfect nature,
establishing great defenses—
when nature is perfected, the heart naturally becomes firm and resolute,
and supreme authority no longer drifts elsewhere.

On one hand, gather spirit and establish unshakable faith and vigilance,
dividing soul, vital essence, and spirit into the four symbols within.
Condense essence to gather the vital essence,
calm spirit to conceal the soul—
since spirit and qi depend on soul and vital essence for their origin,
soul and vital essence are thus gathered into spirit and qi.
When intention is pure and still,
the four symbols cluster in the hidden and secret place—
this is the gathering of the Five Phases’ qi into one,
condensed and firmly established as embryonic essence.

As Master Zhāng said:
*“Two elixirs combined, refining soul and vital essence into sacred spirit.”*
When soul and vital essence are transformed,
spirit naturally condenses,
and my nature and emotions may be steadied.
This chapter, when compared with the forty-fifth above, reveals even greater wonder.

This continues from the two preceding chapters,

○ **Chapter Sixty-Two.**
Determine the will to seek lead and mercury,
quiet the heart to find earth and gold.
Only then does one recognize the true unity—

The will is the matter my nature points toward—
my original resolve.
Earth and gold refer to the stillness of pure yin, the *Kūn* soil concealing a point of *Qián* gold—
when *Wu* rests in *Kūn*, forming *Kǎn*—
this is the initial stir of my true intention.

This follows from the previous chapter:
when nature is steadied, the will is also steadied,
and from this, the seven orifices return to their root.
Focused intent and silent heart
are the method of seeking yang qi and yin essence.
When qi and essence awaken in harmony,
one must still maintain a silent, ashen heart—
this is the way to seek true intention and contain spirit.
Thus, when spirit condenses and qi becomes still,
all return to the true, unerring unity within—
naturally merging to form the Elixir.

Master Bái said:
*“When the will is not scattered, it condenses into spirit.
A silent, ashen heart—within, the Elixir forms.”*
Such profound and abyssal learning—
who can truly recognize it?

○ **Chapter Sixty-Three.**
Creation has no root or stem,
yin and yang have their origin.
These true mysteries—
fathers do not transmit them to sons.

The nameless beginning of Heaven and Earth is the root of creation;
the named mother of all things is the origin of yin and yang.
Indeed!
Yet this most subtle and profound secret
can only be grasped by the heart—
it cannot be easily spoken of.

Let us first speak of creation, yin, and yang by name.
Creation is the power Heaven alone wields to give birth to all things—
the natural, intentional Way of Heaven.
Yin and yang are what man and all things share with Heaven and Earth,
rooted in the boundless, primordial *Yīqì*—
the unborn, unending, empty, and natural Way of non-action.

From non-being arises being—creation;
from being returns non-being—transformation.
This is spoken of in terms of birth and death.
Extreme motion becomes stillness—yin;
extreme stillness returns to motion—yang.
This is spoken of in terms of circulation and return.
Birth and death pertain to form and substance,
circulation and return pertain to spirit and qi.

Since man and all things’ form and substance arise from the condensation of spirit and qi,
when man obtains yin essence and yang qi at the beginning,
spirit is born—
this is the root of life.
Why does this chapter specifically speak of non-action as the root?
Because the world does not know that the **Law of Return** originates from parents,
whose natural essence and qi construct this body.
Once the umbilical cord is severed at birth,
it is as though the root is cut and the stem falls.
Though the spirit and qi received from Great Creation vary in quantity,
determining one’s lifespan—
the virtuous may prolong it slightly,
the unvirtuous may shorten it—
the wise and foolish neither extend nor shorten it,
but follow or resist it, exhausting their allotted measure.
Early or late, all return to dissolution,
once more entering the furnace of Great Creation.
Thus, all things cannot escape fate.

The lifespan’s birth year, month, and day are called *mingzào* (命造), while death’s year, month, and day are called *huàmìng* (化命). The *Exhortation to Virtue* speaks of prolonging life or shortening it, and of fate being exhausted leading to death—all asserting that what is formed must perish, and what is created must transform. Hence, it is said, *"Zàohuà wú gēntí"* (造化无根蒂).

Though the yin essence and yang qi within a human body are also rooted in what Heaven endows, Heaven and Earth themselves rely on these yin and yang to form shapes and bodies. Heaven and Earth merely forget their forms and bodies, not burdening their spirit with material substance, thus using this yin and yang to give birth to all beings.

Humans are the most refined of all things, knowing to revere the high and humble the low, imitating Heaven and following Earth, cultivating emptiness within and substance without to nourish the formless. Within them, the interplay of these two qi moves like the *Wújí Yuānbù* (无极元始) qi—endlessly swelling and waning, like fish in water, perpetually interconnected.

Yet those who do not return to the source are like a single ladle of water or a pinch of earth—played with briefly before the ladle shatters and the pinch scatters, with water returning to the sea and dust to the earth. But those who return to the source naturally align with their origin. A ladle of water preserved without clinging to its vessel remains ever in its source; a pinch of earth settled with sincerity cultivates virtue without ceasing. Over time, water gathers into lakes, earth accumulates into mountains—gradually filling lakes to become seas, embracing emptiness to merge with the *Tàiqīng* (太清), condensing to expand mountains into earth, bearing *Huáyuè* (华岳) with solidity. All this is the original essence of that ladle of water and pinch of earth.

Humans accumulate essence and qi to form spirit, refine emptiness and nourish vastness to attain the Dao—this belongs to the intrinsic response to the source. Laozi’s *"Gǔshén bùsǐ"* (谷神不死) is rooted with Heaven and Earth at the *Xuānpìn* (玄牝) gate! Hence, it is said, *"Yīnyáng yǒu běnyuán"* (阴阳有本源)—though this is only a *zhōngpǐn* (中品) explanation.

As for the *shàngpǐn* (上品) elixir method, there exists a prior move, a direct path through the *Kǒngdào* (孔道), where the *Xuānguān* (玄关) may be instantly realized. One naturally perceives the mysteries of the *Dàodé* (道德) first chapter, knowing that human spirit shares the same *zàohuà* (造化) as Heaven and Earth—that is, the same *Yuānbù miàowúwéi* (元始妙无为) root.

Human qi, like all things, draws from yin and yang—that is, from the *Língbǎo miàoyǒuwéi* (灵宝妙有为) source. It is not like the laborious gathering of multitudes or heaps of earth; it requires only a sincere, unshaken thought, ensuring uninterrupted practice and swift return.

Thus, when discussing *zàohuà* through yin and yang, these belong to the post-heaven realm, manifesting in humans as the *sèsēn* (色身). If lifespan is neither prolonged nor shortened, and one adheres to the *shàn dào* (善道) of guarding death, this is the *Dàrén* (大人) practicing *"Hòutiān ér fèng tiānshí"* (后天而奉天时).

Hence, Yán Zǐ did not die young—not because his *sèsēn* was fated to perish, but because he could *"Chángwú yǐ guān qí miào"* (常无以观其妙). Zháojí did not live long—not because his *sèsēn* was fated to dissolve, but because he failed to *"Chángwú yǐ guān qí miào"*.

If *zàohuà* is understood through yin and yang, then *zàohuà* originates from the pre-heaven realm, manifesting in humans as the *fǎshēn* (法身). If wisdom and fate can restore their source and return to their origin, they naturally respond to all things in constancy, attaining their true nature. This is the *Dàrén* practicing *"Xiāntiān ér tiān bù wéi"* (先天而天不违).

Thus, beings cycle through the *Liùdào* (六道) wheel, while sages and kings cannot become Buddhas because they sacrifice their *fǎshēn* to yin and yang’s likes and dislikes, failing to *"Chángyǒu yǐ guān qí jiào"* (常有以观其徼). The *Wén Dì*’s seventeen incarnations, Laozi’s eighty-one transformations—these follow yin and yang’s movement and stillness, thus able to *"Chángyǒu yǐ guān qí jiào"*.

Hence, it is said:
*"Sèsēn píng zàohuà, yóu tiān bù yóu jǐ"* (色身凭造化，由天不由己)—since one has no root to rely on.
*"Fǎshēn guàn yīnyáng, yóu wǒ bù yóu tiān"* (法身贯阴阳，由我不由天)—since one has a source to penetrate.

Heaven aids the sincere; nothing is unlucky.

Yet all things arise from existence, and existence from non-existence. Non-existence is the source of existence, while existence is the root of non-existence. Thus, existence and non-existence are movement and stillness; movement and stillness are yin and yang; yin and yang are *zàohuà*; *zàohuà* are existence and non-existence.

I need not distinguish between existence and non-existence, yin and yang, creation and transformation. Only in my every movement and stillness do they mutually root, without preference or aversion, following the *Wángdào* (王道).

If one nourishes the *fǎshēn* with the *sèsēn*, then gathering is form, scattering is qi. If one stabilizes the *sèsēn* with the *fǎshēn*, stillness becomes the *Jīndān* (金丹), movement becomes thunderous lightning. What birth, what death, what preservation, what annihilation?

As Mèngzǐ said:
*"Tiān shòu bù èr, xiūshēn yǐ sì zhī, suǒyǐ lì mìng yě."*
(天寿不贰，修身以俟之，所以立命也.)
How could there be a division between life and death?

And again:
*"Wànwù jiē bèi yú wǒ yǐ! Fǎnshēn ér chéng, lè mò zài yān."*
(万物皆备于我矣！反身而诚，乐莫在焉.)
How could there be a distinction between preservation and annihilation?

Thus, one may awaken to the effortless ease of those who are ever responsive and ever still!

Qi is like water, spirit like earth. Qi is what fate depends on; spirit is what nature entrusts. The wise delight in water to nourish qi, acting without contrivance to cultivate wisdom. The virtuous take joy in mountains to solidify spirit, dwelling in earth to cultivate sincerity without wavering, thus fostering tranquility.

Let me exhaust this principle of simultaneously cultivating nature and fate: first, store the spirit in the heart; settle the spirit to still the mind; forget the mind to nourish the form; forget the form to nourish the qi; forget the qi to nourish the spirit; forget the spirit to nourish the void.

Thus, one attains **Master Yan’s** *zuòwáng* (坐忘), exhausting one’s nature to fulfill fate, and further forgetting the void to merge with the Dao—then Heaven itself will grant one sainthood, and the Original Command and Original Nature will naturally return.

When nature and fate are complete, there is no scheming, no certainty, no rigidity, no self—thus merging with the primordial *yīqì* (一氣) of Preheaven, this is the union with the True Dao, transcending past and present while ever enduring, participating in Heaven and Earth without division. In motion, it becomes the eternal constancy of the Great Ultimate; in flow, it is unobstructed. In stillness, it is the True One of the Non-Ultimate, secure and unchanging.

If one attains this constancy, then all impermanence falls under command; if unobstructed, then all obstruction will be penetrated.

As the earlier Confucian scholar Zhouzi (周子) said:
*"The Five Phases are but one yin-yang; yin-yang is but the Great Ultimate; the Great Ultimate originates from the Non-Ultimate."*

The Non-Ultimate is indeed void; the Great Ultimate is indeed existence—the root of transformation, the origin of yin-yang. How could one willingly be bound by yin-yang, confined within the Five Phases, vainly clinging to life while fearing death, debating existence over nonexistence?

One must instead grasp its fundamental root, comprehend its pivotal essence, and transcend the confines of transformation—only then may one be called a true Daoist.

These profound truths, where life and death intersect with colored phenomena, cannot be transmitted by father to son if one does not personally embody and awaken, exhausting principle and fulfilling nature, returning to the True Teacher beneath the divine canopy. With pure mindfulness unfettered, silent and scentless, one must verify it oneself—thus self-stabilizing, self-establishing, self-reverting, self-restoring, self-returning, self-fulfilling, self-liberating. Even the deepest filial bonds cannot convey this.

Hence, the seventh patriarch of Longmen, Master Wang Ziyuan of Kunyang, declared after enlightenment:
*"Recognize the True—run all night,
Seek a pillar with neither existence nor nonexistence.
Empty, vast, and solitary in cultivation,
Neither thirst nor hunger—Heaven’s longevity."*

As stated in the annotations of the Twenty-Two Chapters, *"The advantage of using Six"* is *"eternal constancy,"* while *"The advantage of using Nine"* is *"seeing the dragons without a head—auspicious."*

○ **Chapter Sixty-Three (上第六十三章).**

This follows the preceding four chapters, elaborating on the middle-grade precepts, demonstrating that transformation lacks roots while yin-yang has its source, revealing the beginnings of exhausting principle and fulfilling nature. It teaches self-realization, awakening to life and death, and directly attaining the sacred realm of wondrous existence and wondrous nonexistence—thus returning to the origin and source, aligning with the highest-grade elixir cultivation and verification. Only then does one grasp Confucius’ saying: *"To trace the beginning and the end, thus knowing life and death."* This is what he meant.

This true profundity may now be applied with skill.

This is the pivotal eye-opening insight of the entire passage, elucidating the overarching key of refining the Valley Spirit in Chapters Forty-Nine to Fifty-Four, and setting the stage for the subsequent chapters.

Retain the mercury within the golden cauldron,
And lead into the jade pool.

Host and guest know no left nor right—
Only recognize the infant.

Lead refers to the qi.

The Upper Valley (*Tiāngǔ*), where in infancy the spirit is stored.

The jade pool denotes within the body
The Middle Valley (*Yìnggǔ*), where in infancy the qi is stored.

The infant refers to the Original Command’s return—
The nascent spirit of the Valley’s first transformation.

This follows Chapter Fifty-Four,
Speaking of the moment when the Original Command returns.

This spirit, having been nurtured in the Middle Valley until fullness,
Riding the qi ascends and circulates the Microcosmic Orbit,
Then returns to its original position in the Mud Ball Palace,
Thus remaining in the Upper Valley—this is the Valley Spirit.

The stone child calls this *division of the embryo*,
The white child calls it *transference of the spirit and exchange of the cauldron*—
Hence, *"retain the mercury in the golden cauldron."*

And the qi likewise returns to its original position,
Entering the Middle Valley’s vermilion chamber—
Hence, *"lead into the jade pool."*

This shift requires no artificial effort;
It moves naturally.

Master Zhang’s *Awakening to Reality* states:
*"When using, divide left and right armies—
Let the other be host, I the guest."*

This chapter clarifies its essence,
Teaching that qi should be host and spirit the guest—
No distinction of left or right,
Thus aligning with the Dao’s authenticity and returning to neither death nor birth.

Only when the spirit is securely hidden within
Does it not seek life through external contrivance—
Hence the qi flows boundlessly,
Temporarily retaining the spirit to avoid death.

Only the infant can guard such pure qi,
Thus: *"Host and guest know no left nor right—
Only recognize the infant."*

At this moment, one attains this nascent spirit,
Just as the infant at birth—
Only guard the pure qi as the infant does,
And the pure yang body will naturally flourish!

○ **Chapter Sixty-Four**

Summarizing the past nine chapters,
All elucidating the subtle essence of exhausting principle and perfecting nature,
Revealing the origin of the Original Command’s return,
And the natural functions at the moment of its return.

The next chapter will speak of the method of gentle nurturing.

The Yellow Nurse’s twin breasts are fair,
The Old Man’s single heart is kind.
No other method in gentle nurturing—
Only from the Void, the child is raised.

The Old Man points to the heart:
At the moment of Original Command’s return,
When all is settled and at rest,
One must not cling to any *having*—
Only nurture the formless spirit,
Mastering purity with unwavering devotion,
Guest to lead and mercury in solemn stillness,
Then the qi flows naturally to nourish the spirit-chamber.

Like a nurse feeding her child,
Let it drink as it will,
Her heart tender and yielding,
Following the qi’s course,
Ever watchful and returning—
Thus the body grows uniformly warm,
And the infant thrives naturally, needing no other art.

The Void is the meaning of *not-having*.
As the *Golden Lotus Sutra* says:

Only the method of *Observation of Self-Nature* suffices—
To forget form, forget qi,
And nurture the spirit that is not-spirit.

This follows the previous chapter,

○ **Chapter Sixty-Six**

Within the vessel, the sky of Heaven never darkens,
And fine, white snow descends in delicate flakes.

The crimson gate—
This refers to the **Zhonggu** (Midgut), the place where the **Ying** (Response) resonates in the **Jiangong** (Crimson Palace).
The soaring **Qingfeng** (Azure Phoenix)—
This signifies that at this moment, the **qi** emerges fresh from its original position in the **Jiangong**, like the **Qingfeng** (Azure Phoenix) taking flight.
As the *Yinfu Jing* (Scripture of the Mysterious Response) states: *"The bird is within the qi,"*
Hence, the **Qingfeng** is likened to the **qi**.
The *Shiming* (Explication of Names) says: *"Qing, means 'to generate.'*
Thus, the **Qingfeng** (Azure Phoenix) symbolizes the **qi** in its nascent state.

The **Dantian** (Elixir Field) here refers to the **Upper Dantian**,**—**
That is, the **Tiangu** (Heavenly Grain), the **Nihuan Gong** (Mud Pillow Palace).
The **Yushen** (Jade Hare)—
This denotes the **yang** spirit within the **Gutian** (Grain-Sky), now nurtured and no longer cold as in its initial state, but warm as jade.

The **white snow**—
This signifies the **qi** circulating to the **Gutian** (Grain-Sky), where it mingles with the spirit, forming **shenwater** (spirit-essence).
Its **qi** is clear, pure, and pervasive, like white snow.

At this stage, the **yang** spirit has grown strong and must not be disturbed—
It rests naturally in its **not-spirit** state;
The **qi** flows freely on its own,
Like the **Qingfeng** (Azure Phoenix) ascending to the **Nihuan Gong** (Mud Pillow Palace),
Nourishing this spirit.
When the spirit and **qi** unite, they become **shenwater** (spirit-essence),
And it descends like fine, white snow,
Filling the entire body.
One feels uniformly clear and serene,
As though the body were a sky that never darkens.

○ This is **Chapter Sixty-Six**.
This describes the phenomenon of the **qi** flowing freely during the **warming-nurturing** phase—
Such is the true method of **nurturing life**,
How does it compare to the various minor techniques of life-nurturing in *The Chui Xu Yin* (Jade Emptiness Ode)?
With a **clear heart and bright eyes**, one can surely discern the difference.

After the **qinsè** (zither and se) harmonize, the **jīqiú** (winnowing basket and quilt) is set aside.
The **qi** flows freely without need of **fires** (refining techniques),
Yet one must not fear harming the **baby** (nascent spirit).

This is when the **original spirit** (元神) is tempered and nurtured,
Not the same as before when the **grain spirit** (谷神) was refined by **fires** (火候).
For now, the **grain spirit** has already merged with the **life-qi** (命气),
Just as the **qinsè** has harmonized, and the **qi** circulates freely.
When the **yang spirit** (陽神) is fully matured,
It is the time when the **jīqiú** is truly complete—
No longer bound by **emotions** (情) or **desires** (识好恶).

If one still stirs the **heart-fire** (心火) to refine,
Exhausting the spirit and **violating the qi** (暴气),
Then the **qi** will not fully fill the **emptiness** (虚),
And the spirit will struggle to attain its **completeness** (完夫实).
When will this ever be achieved?
The **yang spirit** will be damaged beyond measure—
Thus one must simply let go of body and mind,
Calm the spirit and still the **qi**,
Let it flow freely on its own,
Naturally filling and complete—
Never probing its **fires** (火候).

○ **Chapter Sixty-Seven**.
This speaks of **nurturing life** (温养) without **forcing** (助长).
Before, one exhausted the **nature** (性) to attain the **life-qi** (命),
Now one must nurture the **life-qi** to guide the **nature** (性),
Only then can one return to the **root source** (本源).

When the **eldest son** (長男) enters **Dui** (Joy),
The **young maiden** (少女) returns to **Qian** (Heaven),
The **Xun Palace** (巽宫) aligns with the **earthly position** (土位),
And the **passageways** (关锁) are sealed within the **Great Circulation** (周天).
The **eldest son** refers to **Lu** (Exposure), symbolizing **yang** (陽) in its nascent form.
The **young maiden** refers to **Dui** (Joy), symbolizing **yang** (陽) now mature—
Entering **Dui** and returning to **Qian**,
This is the **original heaven** (先天) **hexagram** (卦) and **line** (爻) imagery:
The first **yang** (一陽) as **Zhen** (Thunder),
Growing to two lines as **Dui** (Joy)—
**Dui** is the **young maiden** (少女)—
Then to three lines as the **pure yang** (纯陽) **Qian** (Heaven) symbol.
The terms **"just entering"** (才入) and **"already returns"** (便归)
Show how swiftly the **yang spirit** (陽神) matures.

The **Xun Palace** (巽宫) is the **nasal orifice** (鼻窍) of the body.
The **earthly position** (土位) refers to the **physical form** (形体)—
**"Aligning"** (并) is the **Gen-Kun Palace** (艮坤宫) as mentioned in **Chapter Forty-Nine**.
For one **yin** (一阴) is **Xun** (Wind), two **yin** become **Gen** (Mountain),
Three **yin** become **Kun** (Earth)—
This is the **earthly position** (土位).
From the time the **nature** (性) determines the **life-qi** (命),
The **yang spirit** (陽神) initially hides like **Zhen** (Thunder)’s single **yang** (陽),
Concealed within the **heavens**, as the **grain spirit** (谷神) and **life-qi** (命气) flow,
The body grows strong like **Dui**’s two **yang** (二陽),
Then swiftly fills as the **pure yang** (纯陽) **Qian** (Heaven) symbol—
The spirit now dwells in its **proper position** (正位) within the body.

While the **qi** too, like the **Xun Palace**’s single **yin** (一阴), initially rests,
Then stills as **Gen**’s **arrest** (止),
And withdraws like **Kun**’s **concealment** (藏),
Filling the body and flowing freely through the **four limbs** (四肢),
Reaching its utmost perfection!

For the spirit grows stronger through **concentration** (凝),
And the **qi** becomes more abundant through **stillness** (寂),
This is the natural order—
There should be no **excess or deficiency** (偏胜).

Yet within the **uterus** (胞胎), a trace of **blood-qi** (血气) remains uneliminated.
If one does not **guard strictly** (戒严), **withdraw deeply** (深藏), and **keep secret** (宥密),
There is still fear of **excessive movement** (好动) and **not abiding in stillness** (不安于静).
In **movement, stillness, sitting, or lying** (行止坐卧),
If one hears the **nasal breath** (鼻息) as having sound,
Or if the **body** (形体) is **exhausted** (驰骤), **labored** (劳顿),
Then the **qi** will **return to agitation** (返动心),
And the spirit will **constantly stray outward** (神常外驰),
Leading to **leaking the **Passageway** and losing the **qi**** (透关漏气).
Future attainment of the **Dao fruit** (道果) will be **unbalanced** (偏) rather than **complete** (圆),
For the **qi** overpowers the spirit.

Thus it is essential to have **true breath** (真息) flowing **leisurely** (悠悠),
The **body** (形体) **relaxed** (申申),
The **appearance and complexion** (容色) **serene** (夭夭),
Following the **Six Qi** (六气) in their **circulation** (周流),
Conforming to the **Great Circulation**’s **rhythm** (运度),
So the **qi mechanisms** (气机) naturally **seal and lock within** (关锁于内),
Without the **flaws of imbalance or dissipation** (偏胜流失),
This is the **true nurturing of the Great Qi** (善养浩然).

○ **Chapter Sixty-Eight**.
This speaks of the **nurturing life** phase when the **qi** is **strong and mature** (壮盛),
Requiring no **artificial effort** (不假作为),

The **strings** (弦) after and before,
The **full and waning moons** (月圆月缺).

At this time when the **spirit is flourishing** (神旺) and the **qi is abundant** (气足),
The **Great Qi** (浩气) flows freely, filling **heaven and earth** (天地).
One must not let it **agitate** (动荡),
Nor **suppress it** (抑制).
Only **withdraw when full** (因盈而抽) and **supplement when depleted** (因虚而添),
Still applying the **method of firmness overcoming softness** (刚克柔克),
So that this **true qi** (正气) **constantly harmonizes and refreshes** (冲和以为沐浴),
Then the **body** (体) will always be **relaxed and expansive** (舒泰广大宽平),
Waiting for the **original heaven’s yang** (先天元阳) to **encounter summer and return to origin** (遘夏还元).

In summary,
The more **abundant the qi** (气体愈旺),
The more the **spirit withdraws** (则神愈退藏).
Do not let the **spirit be enslaved by the qi** (勿使神为气役),
Then the **yang spirit** (陽神) will naturally attain **completeness** (圆足).

○ **Chapter Sixty-Nine**.
This speaks of the **phase of holding fullness** (持盈),
Ensuring the **spirit is clear** (神清) and the **qi is still** (气静),
Avoiding **excess or deficiency** (过不及) in either.

At this juncture, the three grades within the body have completed the **Pure and Chaste Essence** (太素贞白), and upon obtaining this **true lead of great red** (大赤之真铅), their fusion and congealing—intermingling red and white—yield the crimson.

The **marrow of Heaven and Earth** (天地髓) refers to this very **true lead**. When it is said that the **spirit, qi, and essence** are all fully suffused, utterly undefiled, and ready as **old cinnabar**, it is only that the **nurturing work** is yet insufficient. Once a single point of **true lead** arises and turns crimson, it becomes the **golden elixir of Great Return**.

Yet at this time, the **yang spirit** within the body merely abides in stillness and seclusion. One lets the **Heavenly qi** flow freely, until its completeness is fully realized and the **qi stands motionless in stillness**.

As the **White Boy** said:
*"Concentrate the heart, solidify the spirit,
Attain emptiness, guard stillness—
Then the empty chamber births the white."*

Truly natural!

Then one feels the body steadfast as a towering mountain, vast and high.
Suddenly, a point of **true lead** emerges, deep and piercing—
A radiant red heaven, for this is the **marrow of Heaven and Earth**, the very **original nature returning in summer**.

It stirs the earth and shakes the heavens, surging through the **mixed and chaotic**—
My spirit is thus enveloped in drowsiness,
Unknowing, unaware, as if in deep slumber.

After a moment, one awakens to **clear spirit and refreshed qi**,
The body as if aflame, the heart as ice released.

If speaking of further cultivation,
One must yet engage in **fusion and refinement**;
If speaking of its effects,
Then the **light of nature shines universally**, penetrating the profound and subtle.
One hears the **Nine Heavens**, sees **ten thousand miles**,
The entire body pure **yang**—**golden sinews, jade bones**—
This is the **yang spirit manifesting in form**, able to move freely in nature.

As for the **Dao of longevity**, it is here complete!

Yet fearing that **yang has its yin counterpart**,
And that the **six directions of emptiness** still linger,
Unable to avoid the **coming and going of concealment and revelation**—
How could one then **consort with the Creator** and hold dominion over its beginning and end?

Thus, it is impossible not to **bind together** the **primordial chaos** of the past and the **manifested forms** of now,
And **refine them into the golden elixir of Great Return**.

○ **Chapter Seventy-One**
This follows the meaning of **"seize"** from the previous chapter,

*Clouds disperse over the sea-pink moon,
Spring deepens with willow winds.*
Who knows this intent?
Gazing upward, questioning the void.

**Note:** At this stage, one has obtained the **original official of the Great Polarity** as one’s body.
The **fire and time** is merely **forgetting the void to merge with the Dao**—
A single move where **spirit and qi are entrusted to mutual oblivion**.

Thus, the opening line speaks of **clouds dispersing** while the **moon reaches the sea-pink**—
As if the **spirit is now utterly pure and luminous**, without sound or stench.
The next line speaks of **spring deepening** as the **wind blows through the willows**—
As if the **qi is now perfectly harmonious and unrestrained**, leaving no trace.

Scholars must apply this to **body and mind**,
Completing its structure—
The first line describes the **unmanifest emotions** as the **central equilibrium**,
The second describes **manifested emotions in perfect measure** as **harmony**.

In terms of its function,
The first line models the **Three Penetrations of Virtue** as my **inherent knowing**—
That which all share.
The second models the **Five Penetrations of the Dao** as my **inherent ability**—
That which all follow.

Yet regarding the **mysteries of the Microcosmic Orbit’s fire and time**,
The principle of **gathering and refining** has not yet been entered.

And why does the text then say, *"eyes question the void"*?
This must be **self-body and self-enlightenment**—
Unifying one to comprehend all,
Only able to attain the **original heart’s sincerity**.

Thus, in **action**, one aligns with the **common nature of humanity**,
In **stillness**, one merges with the **original mandate of Heaven**,
Ever nurturing the **undivided whole**—
Then everywhere one touches, it is **penetratingly clear**,
And one knows the **spirit and qi** have long since **naturally fused within heart and eyes**,
And **vanished into the void**.

Why?
The **movement and stillness of qi** follow the **spirit**,
Yet the **spirit is always prior to qi**.
The **ascension and concealment of the spirit** depend on the **heart**,
Yet the **heart is even prior to the spirit**.
The **first impulse of the heart** lies in the **eyes**—
Thus the **eyes are truly the heart’s first impulse**,
The **primary concern of spirit and qi**.

As the *Yin Symbol Classic* says:
*"The heart is born from things, dies from things—
Its mechanism lies in the eyes."*
Thus it is known that the **eyes are the first impulse of the heart**,
The **true priority of spirit and qi**.

If the **eyes flee**, then the **heart withdraws** and **qi is obstructed**, the **spirit perishes**.
If the **eyes are clear and inwardly gazing**, then the **heart is pure**, the **spirit condenses**, and the **qi expands**.
If the **eyes merge with the void**, then the **heart wanders at the origin of things** without attachment,
And the **spirit and qi** remain **serene and ever still**.

When nurturing reaches **stillness without stillness**,
One knows the **ten directions and three realms** are not outside the **One Heart**,
Past and future are not separate from the **One Self**—
Originally unborn, now unextinguished,
Originally unreduced, now unincreased.

This **suchness**—who knows it?

**sun and moon** must **share the furnace**.*
**Advancing fire** must **avoid taboos**,
I **instruct you** to **form Jade Cream**.

**Collecting herbs** must **reunite and congeal**,
**firing** with **mist-bathing**—
until the **embryo’s escape**,
**ninety-nine days** of **yang** **sufficiency**.*

Those who **refine the Golden Elixir**,
must know **winter solstice** is not **at Child**,
**mist-bathing** is not **at Mào Wǔ**.*

**Lead and Mercury** are not **saliva, nasal mucus, or seminal fluid**,
nor **vital breath** or **blood**.

**Seven returns** mean **returning to origin**,
**nine restorations** mean **restoring to source**.*
**Metal’s essence** and **Wood’s essence**,
**meet Earth** and **intermingle**.

**Dragon, Tiger, Horse, Ox**—
all are **formless**.

The **Master’s** *《Awakening to Truth》*,
says the **essence of the Golden Elixir** lies
in the **Spirit-Water Jade Pool**—
that is **Lead and Mercury**.

If one knows **where Lead emerges**,
then one knows **where Mercury is produced**.
Having known **Lead and Mercury**,
one knows the **Spirit-Water Jade Pool**.
Having known the **Spirit-Water Jade Pool**,
one can **refine the Golden Elixir**.

The **Golden Elixir’s merit**,
**achieved in an instant**,
cannot be **measured by nine years or three years**’ **timeline**,
nor **confined to years, months, days, and hours** in **operation**.

**Zhōng Lí’s*** **saying**:
*"The **Four Great Elements** compose **one body**,
all belong to **yin**.*

Thus, one cannot **seek within the body**,
but must **find the single point of yang essence** within it.

Yet this **yang essence**,
dwells in **one orifice**—
**common folk** cannot **guess its location**.

Only this **orifice**,
is the **Primordial Female’s gate**,
the **Spirit-Water Jade Pool** itself.»

Knowing this, one may then **harvest and gather** it,
proceed to **intercourse and fusion**,
then **cook and refine**,
until **bathing in the elixir**,
and **dividing the embryo**—
further requiring **nurturing to perfect the elixir**.

How could one not **discern the river’s source**,
know the **weight in catkins**,
and **grasp the timing**?

Since **Tai Zi** obtained the Master’s **precepts**,
he knew this **body cannot die**.
He knew the **elixir must succeed**.

Now that the **great work** has begun,
this is proclaimed to all **future aspirants of Dao**.
**Stone Tai of the Peach Grove** records this once more.

**Preface to *Elucidating the Return to the Source***

Those who cherish the primordial truth wander through sacred realms, seeking the transmission of the true Dharma, ever aspiring to benefit the world. They abide in singular devotion to the Three Treasures, with particular emphasis on the cultivation of life. For though the study of immortality is most simple, men make it difficult for themselves; though liberation from the dust is not hard, men find it elusive—how lamentable indeed!

As the ancients said:
*"Deluded clouds obscure the moon of wisdom,
Karmic winds stir the sea of stillness."*

Years ago, at a post station, I encountered my late master, the Perfected Zhang Ziyang. In words of utmost simplicity—no more than half a phrase—he revealed effects that manifested in but a moment. Thus I knew that immortality could indeed be learned, and privately rejoiced. When the golden elixir congealed and the sacred embryo attained perfection, I composed *The Return to the Source* in eighty-one chapters of five-character quatrains, offering it to later students that they might early awaken to the true trap. Do not wait until old age, when lead is spent and mercury scarce—awaken swiftly! Seek a master, inquire into the Dao, refine the golden elixir, ascend together the immortal ranks, transform and take flight—this is my deepest wish.

---

**Postscript**

Those who refine the golden elixir must know that the winter solstice does not lie in the *zi* hour, nor is bathing confined to *mao* and *you*. Mercury and lead are neither saliva, essence, qi, blood, nor fluids. The *seven returns* are the return to the root; the *nine reversions* are the return to the source. When the essence of metal and the fluid of wood meet earth, they unite. Dragon and tiger, horse and ox—all are without form.

As my late master’s *Awakening to Reality* states: *"The essence of the golden elixir lies in the divine water of the Flowery Pond"*—this refers to lead and mercury. If one knows the origin of lead, one knows the source of mercury. Knowing lead and mercury, one knows the divine water of the Flowery Pond. Knowing the divine water of the Flowery Pond, one may refine the golden elixir.

The work of the golden elixir is accomplished in an instant—do not cling to the timetable of nine years or three years, nor fixate on years, months, days, or hours for its operation. As Zhongli said: *"The four great elements of the body all belong to yin."* Thus one cannot seek within the body itself, but must seek the single yang essence within it. Yet this yang essence resides in one aperture, which ordinary people cannot fathom. This aperture is the Gate of the Mysterious Female, the very divine water of the Flowery Pond. Knowing this, one may gather and unite, then refine, bathe, and separate the embryo, followed by gentle nurturing. When the elixir is complete, how could one fail to discern its source, know its weight, or recognize its time?

Since receiving my master’s teaching, I have known that this body need not die, and that this elixir must surely be achieved. Now that the great work is underway, I proclaim this to all future seekers of immortality.

*Another postscript by Shi Tai of Apricot Grove.*

---

**Elucidating *The Return to the Source***

*The Return to the Source*, in eighty-one chapters, was composed by the Perfected Shi of Apricot Grove during the Song dynasty. A disciple of the Perfected Zhang Ziyang, he was the second patriarch of the Southern Lineage. Moved by pity for those who study books in pursuit of the Dao yet fail to awaken to their own nature, he wrote this work to repeatedly clarify the path of returning to the root and source.

The method of returning to the source begins with unwavering adherence to right mindfulness. In the midst of daily ethical conduct, one must everywhere restrain anger and suppress desire, acting with sincerity and without pretense, practicing ritual—this is *refining the self*. Silently applying effort to purify the mind and forget emotions, one dredges and opens the *Du* and *Ren* meridians. Through vigilant solitude, one retreats and conceals within the profound—this is *laying the foundation*. Naturally, a single point of true yang qi emerges from the body, and a single drop of true yin essence flows from the heart. These intermingle and congeal into the elixir—this is the *elixir head*.

From this point, the heart naturally abides in sincerity, and qi naturally circulates throughout. Over time, the heart is concealed within the heart yet unseen, and qi is stored within qi yet unfathomable. In stillness, one is empty; in motion, one is direct. Qi is fresh, and spirit is clear—this is *completing the body*. Only when the three temporal realms are fully penetrated, all conditions stilled, the six senses purified, and the square inch of the heart empty and luminous—only then, after a month of unbroken practice, do the medicinal substances flow ceaselessly. Throughout, one operates with pure stillness and naturalness, thereby returning to the source, reverting to the root, and uniting with the Dao—this is *perfecting the true*.

Such is the essence of the golden elixir. Yet the great key lies first in knowing the single aperture within the body, for only then can one begin. This aperture is the window of spirit and brightness, the origin of nature and life. When scattered, it disperses into the seven apertures; when returned to its root, it coalesces into one. Only one who can gather the body with the heart knows how to fathom principle and exhaust nature. Only one who can conceal the heart within the body can exhaust nature and attain life.

For the heart and body are the supports of nature and life, while nature and life are the root and stem of the heart and body. Essence and qi are the functions of the heart and body, while the heart and body are the gathering and storing places of spirit and qi. Thus, one who can gather the body’s qi with the heart causes spirit to return to the Celestial Valley, enabling the fathoming of principle and the exhaustion of nature. One who can conceal the heart’s spirit within the body causes qi to return to the Crimson Palace, enabling the exhaustion of nature and the attainment of life.

Only when principle is fathomed are desires purified; only when nature is exhausted are emotions forgotten. With desires purified and emotions forgotten, nothing disturbs the center. I alone guard the profound mystery of life, and suddenly the single aperture opens wide—this is *opening the barrier*. Perceiving that within it is emptiness without exhaustion, movement without cessation, one follows the transformations of opportunity and allows all to proceed naturally. This is what the *Book of Documents* means by: *"The Dao-heart is subtle; only with precision and unity can one truly hold to the center."* And what the *Dao De Jing* means by: *"The valley spirit does not die; this is called the Mysterious Female. The gate of the Mysterious Female is called the root of heaven and earth."*

Having returned to the root, one recovers life; recovering life, one returns the elixir. How could one not, by tracing the flow to its source, first return to the moment of receiving qi at birth? Returning to my origin, the valley spirit does not die.

Guard well the beginning to secure the end, and the Golden Elixir may surely be accomplished.

(Received) This treatise was graciously bestowed by my late master, the Venerable Tai Xu, who also instructed me in the essentials of superior-grade lead and mercury. I have pondered it in silence, daring not to presumptuously add my own interpretations, until a single word from the master’s illumination suddenly brought full awakening.

The method of returning to the source, as revealed in the sequence of this text, encompasses all oral instructions—from *gathering* and *joining* to *smelting*, *bathing*, *parting the embryo*, *warming and nurturing*, and finally the elixir’s completion and liberation—none other than the repeated elucidation of the Way of returning to the root and restoring the origin, exhausting the subtlest to attain the vastest.

One who cultivates accordingly may enter the inner sanctum of sages and worthies, may ascend the stairway of immortals and buddhas. Now that the karmic conditions have ripened, I reverently honor my master’s intent and expound upon the text’s subtleties. Here, I command my grandnephew Yang Lin to record the following:

**Lead and mercury form the true body;
Yin and yang conjoin the Great Origin.**

The master said: *"Lead refers to the body; mercury refers to the heart. When they meet the Origin in due time, this is the superior-grade elixir path."*

My humble observation: At the moment before birth when one first receives qi, a single aperture forms within, containing essence, qi, and spirit—these three intermingled as one, steaming and swirling within, growing day and night. By the tenth month, when the fetus is fully formed, with a sudden forceful cry, the primordial aperture bursts open, connecting to the seven orifices, and breathing begins.

Within the body, three valleys then emerge: above, the Celestial Valley of Mud Pill Palace, the abode of spirit; in the center, the Resonant Valley of Crimson Palace, the abode of qi; below, the Hollow Valley of Pass of Origin, later to become the abode of essence. At that time, primordial essence has already spread throughout the solid regions of the body and circulates; primordial qi has gathered in the central valley of Crimson Palace to serve as the foundation of life; primordial spirit then floats upward to the Celestial Valley of Mud Pill Palace to serve as the lodging of nature.

Presently, primordial qi stirs and generates yang, beginning to flow into the lower valley of Pass of Origin to become essence—hence the lower valley is also called the Sea of Qi. Yet this essence remains primordial essence, still circulating with qi throughout the body. Whenever stillness reaches its utmost, the seven orifices merge back into one, and within the body, a single point of true yang qi rises to ascend toward the primordial spirit—this is what the elixir path calls *true lead*. Thus, the master designates the body as lead.

Primordial spirit, in stillness, generates yin, which also spreads into the central valley of Crimson Palace to become qi—hence the central valley is also called the Chamber of Spirit. Yet this qi remains primordial qi, still congealed with spirit, constantly generating fluid to nourish the heart. Whenever yang stirs, the single aperture is about to divide into seven, and from the heart first flows a single drop of true yin essence to meet the yang qi—this is what the elixir path calls *true mercury*. Thus, the master designates the heart as mercury.

When lead-qi obtains mercury-essence to circulate, the physical form matures—hence *"lead and mercury form the true body."* When yin-essence combines with yang-qi to ascend, primordial spirit congeals—hence *"yin and yang conjoin the Great Origin."*

In truth, lead refers to the qi within the body, and mercury refers to the essence within the heart—these are the primordial yang-spirit and yin-essence that have descended into the postnatal state, resembling the hidden Qian and Kun within Kan and Li. Yin refers to the qi within the sea, and yang refers to the spirit within the chamber—these are the postnatal lead-qi and mercury-essence returning to the primordial state, resembling the postnatal Kan and Li reverting to Qian and Kun.

Simply by inverting Kan and Li and returning the postnatal to the prior, spirit then lodges in the heart, resembling Qian; qi then relies upon the body, resembling Kun. Kun provides life—hence it is called *body*; Qian provides inception—hence it is called *Origin*. *"True body"* clarifies that the body has not yet leaked, remaining the body of the True One; *"Great Origin"* clarifies that the Origin has not yet dissipated, still holding the primordial of the Supreme Ultimate—both formed spontaneously at birth without reliance on artificial effort.

This chapter establishes the fundamental principle, explicitly pointing to the origin and showing that the body formed by the congealing of essence and qi serves as the foundation of primordial life, while the heart formed by the congealing of spirit and qi serves as the lodging of primordial nature. With body and heart attained, nature and life are complete; essence and qi daily flourish, medicine and fire are both prepared—one need only return daily to the True One.

**Merely knowing the practice of the two eights,
One may refine the Golden Elixir.**

This means that when one attains this body, heart, nature, and life—with spirit relying upon the heart and belonging to Qian, and qi depending upon the body and belonging to Kun—if one can maintain constant clarity and stillness, the seven orifices long remain merged into one, still resembling a single formed Supreme Ultimate. Nature has not yet leaked away, resembling a solid golden elixir. One need only return to emptiness and unite with the Dao to merge with the true Origin—why employ deliberate cultivation with the troubles of restoring nature and life?

Yet after birth, the seven orifices have already become individually perceptive and cannot constantly return to the one aperture. Thus, the undifferentiated is shattered into knowledge, and knowledge in turn transforms into consciousness. From this point, the heart is moved by external things and develops preferences and aversions; the body encounters external things and experiences joy and anger.

The essence within the heart, once drawn by external objects, no longer obeys the governance of primordial nature, constantly chasing outward instead of nourishing the heart. Primordial nature, having no lodging, thus dissipates. The primordial spirit, previously modeled on Qian, now becomes hollow and transforms into Li.

The qi within the body, once stirred by yin-essence, no longer circulates in accordance with primordial life, constantly leaking outward instead of filling the body. Primordial life, lacking sufficient foundation, daily diminishes. The primordial qi, previously modeled on Kun, now becomes substantial and transforms into Kan.

Primordial spirit was originally solid, but by constantly chasing qi, it daily appears hollow. Primordial qi was originally empty, but by constantly flowing into essence, it reverses and appears solid.

At last, the hollow grows ever more hollow, and the solid loses its solidity once more, giving rise to the afflictions of aging, sickness, death, and suffering. This is not due to any inherent flaw in the root or source, but rather the harm of pursuing the branch while neglecting the root, of mistaking the flow for the source.

When spirit loses its solidity, the heart transforms in form to become Li. When qi loses its hollowness, the body likewise transforms in form to become Kan. Thus, the single spark of yang within the postnatal Kan-body is none other than the prenatal primordial qi. In the hexagram’s virtue, it resembles fire within water—hence it is called "yang-qi." The single drop of yin within the postnatal Li-heart is none other than the prenatal primordial spirit. In the hexagram’s virtue, it gathers as water within fire—hence it is called "yin-essence."

The term "two eights" refers to the symbolic numbers within the hexagrams. Kan-water is already formed water, its number six belonging to earth. The fire within water is newly born fire, its number two also belonging to earth—six and two both pertain to earth, forming one of the "eights" of earth. This represents the prenatal primordial qi issuing forth from within my body, metaphorically called "lead." Li-fire is already formed fire, its number seven belonging to heaven. The water within fire is newly born water, its number one also belonging to heaven—seven and one both pertain to heaven, forming one of the "eights" of heaven. This represents the prenatal primordial spirit issuing forth from within my heart, metaphorically called "mercury." Thus, whenever speaking of medicine or fire, one must refer to it as "two eights," and no other number will suffice.

The phrase "practicing the two eights" is precisely the Dao of "timely uniting the primordial," as the master taught—employing only purity and naturalness in its application. Now, recognizing the harm of mistaking the flow for the source and wishing to return to the root, if one does not restrain anger and suppress desires, there is absolutely no way to begin. If one wishes to suppress desires and restrain anger, then uniting and practicing these two eights will make spirit the fire and qi the medicine.

At the time of gathering, it is called "medicine," for it is still postnatal yin-essence and yang-qi. At the time of refinement, it is called "fire," for it belongs to the prenatal—spirit is yang, while qi is yin. Simply knowing how to employ spirit to guide qi is to use fire to refine medicine, which can then form the Great Return Elixir of Golden Liquor.

The term "refinement" implies the need for vigilance against danger and caution against risk, yet it still employs only purity and naturalness in its application. For the yang-qi within my body, now just returning from its temporary abode in the hollow valley, if not congealed by spirit, risks scattering. The yin-essence within my body, now just returning from its temporary abode in the responsive valley, if not circulated by qi, risks sinking back into its former state.

Only by constantly establishing the substance of the Dao through tranquility can one obtain true lead and mercury as the function of the Dao. When using these two substances—lead and mercury—to unite the primordial, they coalesce into one. The proper thought immediately retreats and conceals itself, congealing into profound stillness. Within thought, there is no thought—thus, in an instant, they congeal, returning to the moment when my born body first received qi.

Confucius said, "Essence and qi become things," does this not refer to the true body formed by the congealing of lead and mercury? Laozi said, "There is a thing, undifferentiated and complete," does this not refer to the Great Primordial formed by the congealing of yin and yang? Master Zhang Ziyang said, "Grasp the foundation of Kan and Li, and the three realms return to one body," does this not refer to the pivotal method of practicing the two eights to refine the Golden Elixir?

Thus, lead and mercury are yin and yang; the union of yin and yang is the Great Primordial; the Great Primordial is the true body. The true body, the Great Primordial, is my prenatal "one that becomes two." When timely united, it becomes "two that return to one." Now, one can suddenly awaken!

**Chapter One (conclusion)**
This entire chapter serves as the guiding principle, revealing that body and heart, nature and life, spirit and qi, medicine and fire—all are complete from the very beginning of one’s existence. Thus, it spares no effort in clearly expounding the original source of human life to aid practitioners in personal realization. The following eighty chapters are all annotations to this chapter.

The next seven chapters systematically elucidate the methods of gathering, uniting, and refining. Chapters nine through fifteen teach the secrets of beginning practice. Chapters sixteen through twenty-four expound on the crucial openings, detailing the processes of refinement, bathing, guarding against danger, contemplating risks, as well as the methods of separating the embryo, nurturing, and forming the elixir. Chapters twenty-five through forty-eight re-emphasize the central tenets, unfolding the true mechanism so that readers may have all doubts dispelled.

From chapters forty-nine to sixty-eight, the text clearly instructs on returning postnatal essence and qi to prenatal spirit and qi to form the Valley Spirit. From the Valley Spirit, one refines the yang-spirit, and from the yang-spirit, one further refines to restore the primordial spirit—ultimately returning the primordial spirit to the true Non-Ultimate to become a True Person, thus merging with the Dao in truth. The completion of the Golden Elixir directly reveals the ancient sages’ intent to thoroughly investigate principle, fulfill nature, and attain life—this teaching is earnestly imparted with meticulous steps.

The final three chapters once more invoke the heart-transmission of the ancient sages, earnestly urging the necessary union of spirit and qi, body and heart, nature and life, thereby summarizing the entire work’s meaning. If a practitioner has truly cultivated the work of refining the self, concentrating qi and unifying spirit, holding fast to the singular, numinous, and upright thought, then facing this text, they will naturally perceive the method as exceedingly simple and can immediately enter the Dao through seated practice.

Mercury is the marrow of the Azure Dragon; lead is the fat of the White Tiger. The yin-essence within the heart originally emerges from the fissure of the root of nature. Here, it is called the marrow of the Azure Dragon because alchemists use the Azure Dragon to symbolize the hun-soul. In the prenatal hexagram positions, it belongs to Li, residing in the east—thus Master Zhang referred to it as "the Wood of the Eastern Hun." The prenatal hun-soul remains concealed within Qian, unmoving. In the postnatal state, Qian becomes hollow at its center, transforming into Li. Li resides in the south and pertains to fire—thus Master Zhang also called it "the Fire of the Southern Spirit."

Kan resides in the north and pertains to water—thus Master Zhang also called it "the Water of the Northern Essence."

This po-soul is stored in the lungs, though it still resides in the west, its hexagram has already transformed into the joyous image of Dui, inclined toward gentleness. Its function depends on the body to become essence, for the body is where essence congeals. The yang-qi now surging within me originally stems from the prenatal Metal-qi to become lead—previously likened to "fire within water," yet in truth, it is the fluid of Metal. This speaks of the moment when the two substances, essence and qi, arise—precisely the time for their gathering. The method lies solely in summoning them at will to unite, returning them to the crucible. Thus Kan, now hollow at its center, reverts to Kun, while Li, now replete at its core, returns to Qian. When essence and qi merge within the crucible, Qian and Kun likewise unite to restore the Supreme Polarity. This is called the "elixir head," which Master Zhang termed the "true seed."

To return is to store; the crucible is the orthodox transmission of the *Yi*’s Dao. The alchemists’ watchword has no visible form—it resides at the very center of the sixfold harmony within this body. As the ancients said, "Within lies a true golden crucible," yet it has no fixed location to confine it. The *Yi* states, "The crucible: the noble person rectifies their position and consolidates their mandate."

The "time" refers to the moment when *gui* arises—half of the "living midnight." If one has not yet awakened, one should sit upright in meditation as practice. When stillness reaches its extreme and movement begins, this is the time of *gui*’s arising. Swiftly withdraw the proper thought and conceal it in secrecy for gathering; any diversion of intent will fail. This must not be sought elsewhere.

In sum: the yang-qi within Kan is true lead; the yin-essence within Li is true mercury. Kan and Li give birth to lead and mercury, while lead and mercury arise from body and mind. The function of body and mind is essence and qi, and the substance of essence and qi is nature and life. Extracting the yang from Kan returns it to Kun; filling the void in Li restores it to Qian. These two substances are like a wellspring—qi is primordial qi, essence transforms into spirit. When spirit and qi interact, Kan and Li revert to Kun and Qian. As they wondrously merge and congeal, Qian and Kun blend into the Supreme Polarity. From this point, yin and yang, movement and stillness become each other’s root, binding inseparably, harmonizing indistinguishably, and uniting purely without end.

Is this not the simplest and easiest method of gathering?

---

The maiden rides the lead tiger,
The golden elder straddles the mercury dragon.
The maiden is true mercury,
The golden elder is true lead.
Their names and meanings are detailed in Chapter Ten.
The tiger symbolizes the body,
The dragon symbolizes the mind.
Master Zhang said, "The mind’s wildness is like a dragon,
The body’s ferocity is like a tiger."
"Rides" and "straddles" describe the image of mutual mastery.
When the two medicines are gathered into the crucible,
Yin-essence naturally masters yang-qi,
And yang-qi governs yin-essence,
Forming an undifferentiated whole.
Yet if at this moment tranquility is lacking,
The spirit scatters outward,
And the elixir head dissolves.
One must await the renewed gathering of lead and mercury,
Hence the following admonition to clarify the proper command.

---

*Jia* and *geng* clarify the proper command,
Refining to forge a furnace of red.
*Jia*, belonging to wood, symbolizes nature;
*Geng*, belonging to metal, symbolizes indolence.
The "proper command" is an unbiased decree—
What Confucius called "straightening what is upright,"
What Master Bai termed "the movement of thought as the Mysterious Female,"
And the *Wenyan* of Kun’s second line describes as "the noble person’s reverence to straighten within."
To "clarify the proper command" is to first understand it in ordinary times,
So that when the moment arrives, a single reaffirmation suffices,
And all parts naturally obey.
At the first union of essence and qi,
One must ensure tranquility of nature and ease of emotion
To preserve harmony without dissipation.
The method relies on the power of reverence and sincerity cultivated in advance.
While the mind has not yet stirred,
Swiftly clarify the Dao of nurturing uprightness,
First concealing it in secrecy,
So that within thought there is no thought.
Essence congeals with qi to form spirit,
Emotion returns to nature in great stillness,
And the elixir head solidifies without risk of leakage—
What Mencius called "nurturing with uprightness and causing no harm."
"A furnace of red" is what alchemists call
"A furnace of flame forging emptiness,
The very path of refinement,"
What Mencius termed "fullness radiating brilliance."

---

The serpent’s po seizes the dragon’s marrow,
The tortoise’s hun subdues the tiger’s essence.
The serpent symbolizes emotion,
Which often responds to gentleness with joy—
The work of the po-soul, hence "serpent’s po."
The "dragon’s marrow" symbolizes the yin-essence within the mind.
The tortoise symbolizes nature,
Which often reacts to shock with anger—
The work of the hun-soul, hence "tortoise’s hun."
The "tiger’s essence" symbolizes the yang-qi within the body.
This continues from the previous chapter:
When the proper command is clarified,
Emotion is forgotten and returns to its original nature,
Thus the wild dragon of the mind is captured.
As essence ceases to waver and nature stabilizes,
The root of emotion is severed,
So the ferocious tiger of the body is subdued,
And qi no longer stagnates.
"Seizes" and "subdues" are but acting without contrivance—
As the saying goes, "The tiger is tamed, the dragon is lowered,
The macaque no longer peers through the six windows."
Does this not describe it?

chunks.translated_text:
Within the divine waters of the Flowery Pond,
A single bud of jade fat takes form.
Master Zhang states: "When lead meets mercury, it is called the Flowery Ground; when mercury enters lead, it is called the Divine Water."
In my humble understanding of Master Zhang’s intent:
Lead symbolizes the body, likened to a pond—
When mercury appears, its qi flourishes, hence the name *Flowery Pond*.
Mercury symbolizes the mind, called water—
As it moves in and out of lead, the spirit is invigorated, hence the name *Divine Water*.
When mercury and lead harmonize,
It is but a metaphor for Divine Water entering the Flowery Pond—
In truth, it is only the spirit returning and the body’s qi naturally restored!
When lead and mercury have congealed,
Emotion is forgotten and nature stabilizes,
The spirit enters qi as water returns to the pond.
There is a master ever wakeful,
Like a flower budding with sap, blossoming in joy;
Or jade congealing into fat, dense and solid in form—
Such are the metaphors.
○ Chapter Four above.
This continues from the previous chapter, elucidating that once the two substances have united,
Nature and emotion are rectified, their substance undivided—
Thus the elixir’s foundation is established!

White snow flies in the jasper garden,
Yellow sprouts emerge in the jade orchard.

chunks.translated_text:
"White snow" refers to the body belonging to *kan* (☵). Within *kan*, the single yang is *qian*-metal, hence its color is white. The generation of lead within the body arises from the overflowing of metal-qi; when it encounters mercury and transforms into divine water, bright, pure, and crystalline, it takes on the appearance of snow. *Jasper garden* is a metaphor for the body.

"Yellow sprouts" refers to the heart belonging to *li* (☲). Within *li*, the single yin is *kun*-earth, hence its color is yellow. The generation of mercury within the heart arises from the abundance of wood-fluid; when it meets lead and congeals, it enters the Flowery Pond, blending and flourishing—thus taking on the appearance of sprouting. *Jade orchard* likewise metaphorically refers to this body.

"Flying" and "emerging" describe how, when lead receives the union of mercury, it ascends and permeates, its momentum poised to scatter across the sky; when mercury receives the congealment of lead, it descends and flows, its momentum poised to flourish across the earth.

Master Zixian Xuezi said: *"Without white snow, there are no yellow sprouts. White snow is the divine water of the spirit-chamber; yellow sprouts are the flowers of the qi-pivot."* This serves as verification!

Yet one must not seek them with intention.

chunks.translated_text:
Yet if one can resemble the recumbent moon, where then is the forging of red lead?

To resemble the recumbent moon is but a transformed image of the original mysterious aperture. Before the elixir is obtained within this body, one maintains inner purity and guards the One—all seven apertures return to the single aperture. Within it, emptiness and numinous clarity stand open, round and whole as an egg, for in stillness it contracts. When the elixir arises, the moment one’s true command arrives, the aperture turns upward like a vessel to receive the medicine, for as it is about to move, it also begins to open. Viewed from the side at that moment, its form resembles the recumbent moon. Once the medicine is received and merges into darkness, it returns to the egg-like guarding. For the instant a thought stirs, it settles again—the mysterious aperture opens only to contract once more. If moved by emotion and the heart stirs, the aperture will open into seven, and the medicine scatters. Thus, the ability to resemble the recumbent moon serves as verification of receiving the medicine. Yet this describes only its likeness, for it arises spontaneously, without form or substance to behold.

Red lead, as Master Zhang states, is “true lead born in Kan, whose function lies in the Li palace”—the transformation from black to red. Yet even this has no color or appearance. To ask “where is it forged” is to remind that spirit has no fixed form, warning against attachment to deliberate action. This is what Mencius meant by “there must be doing, yet without fixation.”

In essence, once the cinnabar head is established, the medicinal substances arise at all times. If one can only clarify the true command, no external distractions will intrude. Within, it will naturally receive at all times. Over time, with qi abundant and spirit full, the Valley Spirit will naturally be replete.

For the cultivator, at first one suffers from not knowing the aperture; once the aperture is understood, one must vigilantly guard against its severance. Withdrawal and concealment beforehand are essential—purity and stillness are wondrously subtle. If one can withdraw and conceal beforehand, then when the moment arrives, one will not miss the opportunity, and subsequent thoughts will not disturb. Knowing this, the heart can be rectified!

Above, Chapter Five.
